docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a hospital-based doctor for more than three decades, now long in the tooth and gray at the temples, I disagree with Peter Salgo about the best tactic for restoring the doctor-patient relationship. He proposes that patients take the lead in restoring it by confronting the insurance behemoths that control reimbursement. But doctors should not use patients to fight the battle that should rightly be borne by them and the organizations they have created to represent them.

headline.main: Balancing the Doctor and the Patient

docs.abstract: Dr Paul Bloustein letter disputes Peter Salgo's contention that patients should take lead in restoring doctor-patient relationship by confronting insurance behemoths; holds that doctors should not use patients to fight their battles (March 22 Op-Ed article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     As a hospital-based doctor for more than three decades, now long in the tooth and gray at the temples, I disagree with Peter Salgo about the best tactic for restoring the doctor-patient relationship.      He proposes that patients...

docs.lead_paragraph: As he sought the Democratic Party's presidential nomination in 2004 and later as John Kerry's running mate, John Edwards talked about poverty more than any other candidate. But when he spoke on the campaign trail about what he referred to as the ''two Americas,'' he told a conference on poverty here this week, ''people called it a downer.''

headline.main: With an Eye on Politics, Edwards Makes Poverty His Cause

docs.abstract: Former senator and vice-presidential contender John Edwards has made curbing poverty centerpiece of his work and his political approach; is presumed contender for Democratic Party's 2008 presidential nomination; organized poverty conference at University of North Carolina, and has campaigned in several states for initiatives to raise minimum wage and on behalf of unions for service sector groups; shies away from protectionism and believes promoting unions is best way to make impact; photo (M)
docs.snippet: John Edwards, a presumed contender for the 2008 presidential nomination, has made curbing poverty the centerpiece of his work.

docs.lead_paragraph: KNOCKED on their heels, several companies struggled with setbacks this week. General Motors and Microsoft took steps to cope with problems long in coming, while federal prosecutors were staggered by a reversal in a very visible corporate corruption case. SILVER HANDSHAKES -- Unable to sell enough cars to keep its employees busy, General Motors offered to pay them to go away. In an agreement with the United Automobile Workers union, G.M. offered $35,000 to $140,000 to its 113,000 employees in North America if they agreed to leave their jobs. It also extended the offer to more than 20,000 employees of its quasi-independent supplier, Delphi.

headline.main: G.M. Offers Pay for Its Workers to Go Away

docs.abstract: Mark A Stein Five Days column; General Motors, in agreement with United Automobile Workers union, offered $35,000 to $140,000 to its 113,000 employees in North America if they agreed to leave their jobs; also extended offer to more than 20,000 employees of its auto supplier Delphi; federal appeals court overturned obstruction-of-justice conviction of Credit Suisse First Boston banker Frank P Quattrone; Microsoft said its new computer operating system, Windows Vista, would not be available to customers before Christmas, as it had planned; Bayer said it would pay nearly $20 billion in cash for Schering, topping $17.9 billion offer by Merck of Germany; Zurich American Insurance Co, American subsidiary of Zurich Financial Services of Switzerland, agreed to pay $171.7 million to settle accusations of commercial insurance price fixing and bid rigging; Federal Judge Mariana R Pfzelzer found Gemstar-TV Guide former executive Henry C Yuen liable for securities fraud; L'Oreal of France agreed to buy Body Shop International for about $1.14 billion; Colgate-Palmolive acquired 84 percent stake in Tom's of Maine for $100 million; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Knocked on their heels, several companies, including General Motors and Microsoft, struggled with setbacks this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Goodman's employer, a telecommunications company in Boston, offers benefits to help employees care for elderly parents. But she found them nearly useless during four years of caring for her mother, who has Parkinson's disease, and her father, who died of kidney failure last year. ''They say they want to do the right thing,'' Ms. Goodman, 58, said of her employer, which she would not identify for fear of losing her job. ''But when it comes down to it, they're not seeing the true picture.''

headline.main: As Parents Age, Baby Boomers And Business Struggle to Cope

docs.abstract: Nancy Goodman's employer, telecommunications company in Boston, offers benefits to help employees care for elderly parents, but she found them nearly useless during four years of caring for her mother, who has Parkinson's disease, and her father, who died of kidney failure last year; Goodman's lament is common, as corporate America scrambles to help soaring number of baby boomers, mostly working women, whose obligation to frail, elderly parents results in absenteeism, workday distractions or stress-related health problems; companies are responding, but experts say they often use child care benefits as model when they do not suit different and unpredictable needs of elderly; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Companies are scrambling to help the soaring number of baby boomers who are caring for elderly parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, people who did their insurance business with Prudential, one of New Jersey's signature companies, were told that they owned ''a piece of the rock.'' Now, people may have an opportunity to own a piece of other prominent state symbols: the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway. Under a bill introduced this week by State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, a Democrat from Union County, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority would set up a new corporation and sell a 49 percent stake of the turnpike and the parkway to investors. And while the bill would limit any toll increases to the rate of inflation, Mr. Lesniak said the sale would raise $6 billion and help pay down the state's pension liabilities.

headline.main: For the King of the Road in New Jersey, a Possible Chance to Buy a Share of the Turnpike

docs.abstract: New Jersey State Sen Raymond J Lesniak introduces bill to allow New Jersey Turnpike Authority to set up corporation to sell 49 percent of New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway to investors; money will be used toward pension liabilities; other cities and countries have already sold or leased their toll roads (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 28,000 doormen, janitors and other service workers at 3,500 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens rejected yesterday the building owners' demand that workers accept a one-year pay freeze and pay 15 percent of their health premiums. The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners and managers, said a pay freeze was warranted because owners have already agreed to pay more for health coverage and because they are also being squeezed by higher taxes and energy costs. The building workers pay nothing toward their health premiums, which total around $10,000 per year per worker. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, has threatened a strike on April 21 if no agreement is reached by then. STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Workers Reject Pay Freeze

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union rejects New York City building owners' demand that workers accept one-year pay freeze and pay 15 percent of health premiums; union threatens strike on April 21 (S)

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medicare program agreed yesterday to pay for a $400 test from Cambridge Heart to screen out heart patients who are not likely to benefit from an implanted defibrillator. The test is needed to evaluate patients at risk of sudden cardiac death, which kills about 350,000 Americans a year, Medicare said on its Web site.
docs.abstract: Medicare agrees to pay for $400 test from Cambridge

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN politicians speak of America's health care needs, they often miss an important point: the doctor-patient relationship has become frayed. Patients aren't unhappy just because health care costs too much (though they would certainly like it to be more affordable). Rather, people sense a malaise within the system that has eroded the respect they feel patients deserve. There has been a shift in attitude within the profession. I see examples of it every day. I was making rounds in my intensive care unit recently when one of the interns presented a case. ''This is the first admission for this 55-year-old male,'' he said.

headline.main: The Doctor Will See You for Exactly Seven Minutes

docs.snippet: Turning doctors into shopkeepers who regard patients as customers is unacceptable.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new drug hailed last year as a breakthrough for black heart patients has become a major disappointment for its maker, NitroMed, and the company announced yesterday that two top executives involved in bringing the product to market had resigned. NitroMed, based in Lexington, Mass., released a statement announcing the departure of the chief executive, Michael D. Loberg, and the chief business officer, Lawrence E. Bloch.

headline.main: 2 Officials Quit Amid Slow Sales of Heart Drug for Blacks

docs.abstract: NitroMed chief executive Michael D Loberg and chief business officer Lawrence E Bloch resign amid slow sales for heart drug BiDil; drug was introduced last year after Food and Drug Administration made it first drug approved for use by blacks only; sales last year were only $4.5 million, with BiDil hampered partly by insurance reimbursement problems and possibly by its small marketing force; chairman Argeris N Karabelas is named interim chief executive; Kenneth M Bate will succeed Bloch (M)
docs.snippet: A new drug hailed last year as a breakthrough for black heart patients has not lived up to expectations for NitroMed.
